title: How to Use a Norwex Window Cloth

steps.title: Spritz the glass with water.
steps.content: Spritz the glass with water. Take a spray bottle filled with cool or lukewarm water and lightly mist the glass surface or mirror. Don’t use too much water—the Window Cloth only needs a little bit of moisture to buff and clean any streaks off of glass. [1] X Research source If you want to do a more thorough cleaning, start by wiping down the surface with a damp EnviroCloth. You don’t need to use a special glass cleaner, since Window Cloths can disinfect areas with just water. [2] X Research source Window Cloths can also be used on chrome, crystal, and stainless steel.

steps.title: Fold the Window Cloth in half twice so it looks like a small square.
steps.content: Fold the Window Cloth in half twice so it looks like a small square. Take the cloth and fold it lengthwise so the material resembles a square shape. Next, make the cloth more compact by folding it in half again. Folding the cloth makes it easier to manage throughout the cleaning process. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Clean off the surface with a Norwex Window Cloth using long strokes.
steps.content: Clean off the surface with a Norwex Window Cloth using long strokes. Take a regular Norwex Window Cloth and dry off the edges and corners of the windows. [4] X Expert Source Ashley Matuska Professional Cleaner Expert Interview. 15 April 2019. Use long, straight strokes to ensure that all the water is gone from these hard-to-reach places. Go over these spots more than once, if needed. [5] X Research source Make sure that the cloth is flat whenever you use it, or else the microfibers won’t be as effective. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Buff away any remaining moisture with long wipes.
steps.content: Buff away any remaining moisture with long wipes. Polish the center of the window in the same way that you dried the edges and corners. [7] X Research source Using broad, vertical strokes, work from left to right or right to left as you dry and buff the remainder of the window. [8] X Expert Source Ashley Matuska Professional Cleaner Expert Interview. 15 April 2019. Check to make sure there’s no leftover moisture on the glass when you finish wiping.

steps.title: Start a normal wash cycle with mild detergent and cold water.
steps.content: Start a normal wash cycle with mild detergent and cold water. Pour less than 0.25 cups (59 mL) of mild detergent into the washing machine. [9] X Research source Choose a light or normal spin speed with cool or cold water when you go to start the load. [10] X Research source For extra security, place your Window Cloths in a mesh laundry bag before sticking them in the washing machine. [11] X Research source Don’t use bleach or fabric softener, as these will damage the material. You can also use a washer to clean your EnviroCloths.

steps.title: Dry your Window Cloth in the dryer with Norwex dryer balls.
steps.content: Dry your Window Cloth in the dryer with Norwex dryer balls. Remove your window cloths from the mesh bag before transferring them to the dryer. Norwex makes special dryer balls that work as fabric softener for the microfiber material without damaging it in the process. Add these balls to the machine before starting a normal drying cycle at a low to moderate temperature. [12] X Research source If the material is still damp when it comes out of the dryer, let the Window Cloth air-dry for a few hours.

steps.title: Wash your Window Cloth by hand if you’d prefer not to use a washer.
steps.content: Wash your Window Cloth by hand if you’d prefer not to use a washer. Soak the Window Cloth under running water before folding it in half lengthwise. Once folded, rub both halves against one another to remove any dirt and grime. Wring any excess water out of the material before leaving it to air-dry overnight. [13] X Research source Add a tiny amount of dish soap during the rubbing process if you want your Window Cloth to be extra clean. [14] X Expert Source Ashley Matuska Professional Cleaner Expert Interview. 15 April 2019. If you use your Window Cloth in the kitchen a lot, consider draping it over the oven door, or along the top of a kitchen chair. If you’d prefer to use a hook, Norwex Window Cloths also come with a hanging loop stitched into the material.
